history.content:
From my personal experience working at a Fortune 100 company, internships have been less workload than coursework, but take in mind this is an internship, and they generally don't give out extensive/hard projects. They are more for the interns to learn and for the company to gauge how well the candidate is able to work within a team.

Also, it may seem like its less work also because you are getting paid to work 9-5, where you have a set time to work and do work, whereas during school, I procrastinate all day.

children.subject: I would say the workload is around the same but it's compressed into a 9-5 schedule as opposed to spreading it out over the course of days with several breaks in between like we tend to do with CS coursework.

This is coming from someone who is working full time at a startup as a Senior level software engineering role while being a full-time student for the past two semesters:

They are totally different comparisons. A lot of what you do in projects at UCB are designing and building code and software. 
In my experience, there is a lot of fixing and maintaining of the code base and system structure all the time. - This is more hands on and frankly almost no coding at all (most of the time).
The difference between software engineering and being a computer scientist is a feat of how applicable you can solve a real life problem in real time.
Compared to my internships in the past, I'd say that the workload at work as a full-time (since mine is a startup) is far more rigorous and demanding than coursework because you have to learn something,
where hand holding and structured teaching doesn't exist and you have to self-learn and own up to responsibilities that really aren't your creations, which takes more time than you'd think.
It depends on you here because how driven you are will give you that satisfaction of doing something great or stressing out because you've got too much.
I was lucky enough to have a great boss and know the CTO and directors to take sometime off when necessary for school for like midterms, finals, and projects when the workloads intersected with work deadlines.
What you should worry about most of the time is your manager/boss, because they will stem your workflow and help you when you need it most or make things worse.
Most tech companies don't do the whole 9-5 thing because they really just care about how much work you get done or how many tasks you have completed since most are salary based.
Also, it should be noted that those in the industry will work longer and harder because of that bonus and their stock options/units.

history.content:
I know in this Piazza realm we often ask about the workload of specific classes, but to pose a parallel question, I am curious about how workload in industry compares to projects we do in classes at Berkeley?

Are projects at Facebook or other companies typically more easy/difficult than say, 162 pintos or 61B bearmaps, and in what ways are they different, especially regarding how debugging is done? 

Of course this will depend a lot on the team within the company, but I'm just curious to what extent hair pulling or joyful collaboration is done compared to various school projects.
history.subject: Workload of Industry?
